Unnamed Group of People.Sourced Statement: Multiple contemporaneous comments called him a “god”; one commenter heralded the task as “the pinnacle of human brain potential.”
Unnamed Group of People.Source Justification: Multiple contemporaneous comments called him a “god”; one commenter heralded the task as “the pinnacle of human brain potential.”

Unnamed Group of People.Sourced Statement: “I had no idea he could do shit like that,” someone uttered in the crowd, in awe, in a video of his display.
Unnamed Group of People.Source Justification: someone uttered in the crowd, in awe, in a video of his display.

Named Person Sources.Sourced Statement: “It wasn't anything serious,” he told Gazetteer SF over FaceTime from his home in Hayward. “I wasn't extremely good at the game or anything.”
Named Person Sources.Source Justification: Chris Chike is, by most accounts, the greatest Dance Dance Revolution player in the world.

Named Person Sources.Sourced Statement: “He's the GOAT,” according to friend Roger Clark, a San Francisco programmer and longtime DDR enthusiast. “Everybody knows it. No one would deny it.”
Named Person Sources.Title of Source: San Francisco programmer and longtime DDR enthusiast
Named Person Sources.Source Justification: friend Roger Clark, a San Francisco programmer and longtime DDR enthusiast

Named Person Sources.Sourced Statement: “I don’t think I would have any other reason to take it so seriously if it wasn’t for the community and the competition,” he said. “You discover this group of people who’s really like-minded. It’s a really rare thing, because out in the normal world, there’s not a lot of people who think like me or have similar hobbies or have the grinder mentality for video games like me.”
Named Person Sources.Source Justification: Chris Chike is, by most accounts, the greatest Dance Dance Revolution player in the world.

Named Person Sources.Sourced Statement: “Whenever you meet someone who plays DDR, you kind of don't really care that much what they're doing outside of the game, right?” Clark said.
Named Person Sources.Title of Source: San Francisco programmer and longtime DDR enthusiast
Named Person Sources.Source Justification: friend Roger Clark, a San Francisco programmer and longtime DDR enthusiast

Named Person Sources.Sourced Statement: “I was, like, I get to quit and have severance at the same time — it was almost a win-win, ‘cause I was already a little bit checked out,” he said.
Named Person Sources.Source Justification: Chris Chike is, by most accounts, the greatest Dance Dance Revolution player in the world.

Named Person Sources.Sourced Statement: “I don't think I can physically do this forever,” he said. “I'm getting up there, I just turned 33 this week. So I'm just taking advantage of it while I can.”
Named Person Sources.Source Justification: Chris Chike is, by most accounts, the greatest Dance Dance Revolution player in the world.

Named Person Sources.Sourced Statement: “This is the best that anyone in the human race could possibly achieve at this thing,” Clark told Gazetteer.
Named Person Sources.Title of Source: San Francisco programmer and longtime DDR enthusiast
Named Person Sources.Source Justification: friend Roger Clark, a San Francisco programmer and longtime DDR enthusiast

Named Organization Sources.Sourced Statement: for his prowess at pretending to play the song, the Guinness Book awarded him a record for best Guitar Hero player in the world.
Named Organization Sources.Source Justification: for his prowess at pretending to play the song, the Guinness Book awarded him a record for best Guitar Hero player in the world.

Named Organization Sources.Sourced Statement: In 2017, shortly after Chike won the Konami Arcade Championship (the World Cup of DDR), Clark accompanied him to an arcade in San Jose called Round1, where he planned to set a world record: Completing a level 19 DDR song, the highest level currently available, with absolutely perfect timing.
